text:
WASHINGTON – Federal tax credits could help lower tax bills for many Americans this filing season.

A tax credit is different from a tax deduction, which lowers the amount of an individual's taxable income. Tax credits are often more valuable compared to deductions because they directly reduce your tax bill, dollar-for-dollar.

Tax credits can be nonrefundable, refundable or partially refundable. Here's what to know when filing your taxes this year:

What is a tax credit?

A tax credit is a dollar-for-dollar amount an individual can directly subtract from their tax return to reduce the tax they owe. This can lower the total tax payment or increase the refund amount.

Tax credits are more favorable than tax deductions because they reduce the tax due, not just the amount of taxable income, according to Investopedia.

Tax credits are available for a variety of expenses, including purchasing health insurance through the marketplace, paying for higher education and covering childcare costs.

Federal tax credits for electric vehicle purchases and energy‑efficient home upgrades are no longer available for 2026, after their eligibility deadlines passed in late 2025, according to NerdWallet.

How do refundable tax credits work?

Refundable credits are paid out in full, and a taxpayer also gets a refund for any remaining credit that's still available. Some taxpayers who aren't required to file may still want to do so to claim refundable tax credits.

There are several types of refundable tax credits, such as the Premium Tax Credit, which helps individuals and families cover the cost of health insurance premiums purchased through the health insurance marketplace.

The Earned Income Tax Credit is for low‑ to moderate‑income workers who meet eligibility rules based on income and family size.

For 2026, the IRS increased maximum earned income tax credit amounts to:

Up to $664 for workers without children.

Up to $4,427 for those with one qualifying child.

Up to $7,316 for those with two qualifying children.

Up to $8,231 for those with three or more qualifying children.

How do nonrefundable tax credits work?

For nonrefundable tax credits, once a taxpayer's amount owed reaches zero, they won't see any leftover amount as a refund.

Some nonrefundable tax credits must be used in the year they are claimed and expire if unused, according to Investopedia. Others, such as the Adoption Credit, may be carried forward to future years.

Nonrefundable tax credits can negatively impact low-income taxpayers because they cannot use the entire amount of the credit.

How do partially refundable credits work?

Some types of credits are partially refundable. One example is the American Opportunity Tax Credit for postsecondary education students.

Under this credit, if a taxpayer reduces their tax liability to zero before using the entire $2,500 credit, the remaining portion may be taken as a refundable credit up to the lesser of 40% of the remaining credit or $1,000, according to Investopedia.

title: Natural gas for near-term delivery soars to three-year highs | American Press
description:
Prices for near-term deliveries of U.S. natural gas continued to soar on Monday, rising by almost 28% as a period of cold temperatures settled over much of the country, causing demand to rise and supplies to fall.
The price of natural gas for March delivery settled at $3.901 per million btu, up by 8.8% from the week prior.
According to financial firm LSEG, U.S. gas production hit a two-year low 92.6 billion cubic feet on Sunday, mostly due to frozen wells, but output is expected to rise to 95.5 billion cubic feet on Monday.
This compares with a recent high of 110.0 billion cubic feet of gas produced on Jan. 12, and an all-time daily high 111.2 billion cubic feet on Dec. 21.
Supplies of natural gas over the medium- and long-term are seen as adequate.
text:
Prices for near-term deliveries of U.S. natural gas continued to soar on Monday, rising by almost 28% as a period of cold temperatures settled over much of the country, causing demand to rise and supplies to fall.

The jump in the price of natural gas, which is used in about 60% of American homes for heat or to power major appliances, comes as nearly half of all states declared winter weather emergencies and sub-freezing temperatures spread across the country.

The increase has occurred primarily in the price of near-term contracts, while gas for deliveries in March and April were up only slightly on Monday.

The benchmark contract at the Henry Hub in Louisiana for gas delivered in February settled at $6.806 per million btu, the highest price since December 2022, and an increase of 131% during the last week. The price of natural gas for March delivery settled at $3.901 per million btu, up by 8.8% from the week prior.

Phil Flynn, an analyst at the Price Futures Group, said winter gas demand in late January is at its peak, while freeze-offs caused by extreme cold in major producing states are reducing supply, putting pressure on pipelines and power grids across the country.

“These volatile price movements are directly tied to escalating heating needs, massive, expected storage withdrawals and production setbacks from freeze-offs,” said Flynn.

According to financial firm LSEG, U.S. gas production hit a two-year low 92.6 billion cubic feet on Sunday, mostly due to frozen wells, but output is expected to rise to 95.5 billion cubic feet on Monday.

This compares with a recent high of 110.0 billion cubic feet of gas produced on Jan. 12, and an all-time daily high 111.2 billion cubic feet on Dec. 21.

In addition to unseasonably cold temperatures, analysts say the rapid increase in LNG exports in recent years is another factor behind the short-term increase in the price of natural gas. The U.S. Energy Information Administration, an agency within the Department of Energy, estimates U.S. exports of LNG will average 16.3 billion cubic feet per day in 2026.

Supplies of natural gas over the medium- and long-term are seen as adequate. On Jan. 16, the agency reported gas held in U.S. storage tanks was 4.8% higher than the previous year and 6.1% above the 5-year average for the same time of year.

name: Congress
title: Frustrations rise over ethanol ahead of Trump's Iowa speech - E&E News by POLITICO
authors: Grace Yarrow, Hannah Northey, Sara Schonhardt, Adam Aton, Scott Waldman
description:
Tensions remain high over the future of ethanol sales as President Donald Trump prepares to give a highly anticipated speech on energy and the economy in Iowa on Tuesday.
A last-minute push to include a provision green-lighting year-round E15 sales in Congress’ funding package fell apart last week, much to the dismay of struggling corn farmers who were hoping it would open new markets.
House Republicans agreed to set up a new energy working group to discuss the path forward for ethanol, potentially in a supplemental package this spring.
Still, the failed effort left lobbyists feeling betrayed by the White House and farm-state lawmakers feeling frustrated with a key agriculture industry group, according to three people granted anonymity to discuss behind-the-scenes conversations.
Advertisement The National Corn Growers Association rankled Midwestern Republicans on Wednesday when it dismissed the effectiveness of the new ethanol working group.

name: North Carolina Environment
title: New Carbon Plan course teaches the public how to share their energy story
description:
Duke Energy and state regulators are deciding how to address rising energy demand in the Carolinas — demand that’s being driven, largely by incoming data epicenters.
A Charlotte nonprofit is educating folks on how to get involved and provide feedback on Duke Energy’s proposed Carbon Plan.
“This course is really designed for the average person, just trying to understand really complex technical information behind the Carbon Plan,” said Brittany Griffin, CleanAIRE NC’s advocacy manager.
State regulators are holding public hearings for Duke’s Carbon Plan starting next week: Feb. 4: Durham County Courthouse Mar.
18: Mecklenburg County Courthouse These conversations will determine how much energy we get from clean energy sources, like solar, and how much from fossil fuels.
text:
Duke Energy and state regulators are deciding how to address rising energy demand in the Carolinas — demand that’s being driven, largely by incoming data epicenters. A Charlotte nonprofit is educating folks on how to get involved and provide feedback on Duke Energy’s proposed Carbon Plan.

“This course is really designed for the average person, just trying to understand really complex technical information behind the Carbon Plan,” said Brittany Griffin, CleanAIRE NC’s advocacy manager.

The CleanAIRE Academy course covers the history of these Utility Commission proceedings, starting with HB 951, the law that instructed Duke Energy to file a biennial plan to reach carbon neutrality by 2050. It also includes lessons on how to effectively communicate experiences with air pollution, utility bills and energy.

“A big component is actually how to take action, how to begin with crafting an effective message,” said Rafi Vaca, the nonprofit’s education manager.

The whole course takes less than an hour. At the end, participants can practice drafting a public comment and receive feedback from Griffin on how best to make their voices heard.

State regulators are holding public hearings for Duke’s Carbon Plan starting next week:

Feb. 4: Durham County Courthouse

Mar. 4: New Hanover County Courthouse

Mar. 16: Virtual

Mar. 17: Buncombe County Courthouse

Mar. 18: Mecklenburg County Courthouse

These conversations will determine how much energy we get from clean energy sources, like solar, and how much from fossil fuels.

title: Winter Storm Fern Impact on US Energy Markets 2026 - Discovery Alert
description:
This comprehensive analysis of winter storm Fern impact on US energy markets provides crucial insights into the vulnerabilities of modern energy infrastructure.
The Structural Fragility of America's Energy Grid Modern energy infrastructure operates as an interconnected web where disruptions in one sector trigger failures across others.
Winter Storm Fern's impact is likely to catalyse significant changes in energy infrastructure investment priorities, regulatory frameworks, and technology adoption patterns.
Furthermore, the renewable energy transition must consider resilience factors alongside decarbonisation goals to ensure reliable energy supply during extreme weather events.
However, winter storm Fern impact on US energy markets demonstrated that current preparation levels remain inadequate for extreme scenarios.
text:
How Does Extreme Weather Expose Critical Vulnerabilities in US Energy Infrastructure?

Winter Storm Fern's devastating impact on American energy systems revealed fundamental weaknesses that extend far beyond temporary weather disruptions. The crisis demonstrated how interconnected vulnerabilities across multiple energy sectors can cascade into systemic failures, exposing the fragility of infrastructure designed for normal operating conditions rather than extreme weather events. This comprehensive analysis of winter storm Fern impact on US energy markets provides crucial insights into the vulnerabilities of modern energy infrastructure.

The Structural Fragility of America's Energy Grid

Modern energy infrastructure operates as an interconnected web where disruptions in one sector trigger failures across others. During Winter Storm Fern, this interconnectedness became a liability rather than a strength, as production losses cascaded through the entire energy supply chain.

The scale of infrastructure failure during the storm was unprecedented in recent memory. Electricity markets experienced extraordinary price volatility, with day-ahead prices in the PJM Interconnection reaching $638 per megawatt-hour, representing a staggering 550% increase from normal winter levels.

This surge marked the highest electricity prices recorded since 2014, while New York markets saw even more extreme spikes to $680 per megawatt-hour. Furthermore, the US oil production decline highlighted broader structural issues facing domestic energy production.

Energy Sector Impact Magnitude Recovery Timeframe Oil Production 2 million barrels/day curtailed 7-10 days Natural Gas Output 10+ billion cubic feet/day reduction 5-7 days Electricity Generation 550% price spike in PJM region 7 consecutive days Port Operations 57% reduction in Gulf Coast loadings 4-6 days

Multi-Commodity Supply Chain Interdependencies

The storm revealed how natural gas production shut-ins create ripple effects throughout electricity generation systems. When wellhead freeze-offs reduced gas supply by more than 10 billion cubic feet daily, power generators faced immediate fuel constraints during peak heating demand periods.

North Dakota's Bakken Basin provided a stark example of upstream vulnerability. Production cuts of 100,000 to 110,000 barrels per day represented approximately 10% of the state's total output, caused entirely by freeze-offs at wellhead facilities. These failures occurred despite winterization efforts implemented following previous extreme weather events.

Transportation bottlenecks amplified regional price disparities as the storm progressed. Gulf Coast ports in Texas and Louisiana managed to load only 6 million barrels of crude between January 24-27, compared to the December 2025 average of 3.8 million barrels per day.

This 57% reduction in export capacity created immediate supply constraints for international markets while domestic inventories accumulated. In addition, critical minerals in the energy transition became increasingly important for building resilient infrastructure.

The crisis exposed critical gaps in cross-sector resilience planning. Unlike single-point failures that can be isolated and contained, Winter Storm Fern's impact demonstrated how weather-related disruptions propagate through interconnected energy systems, creating compound effects that exceed the sum of individual sector impacts.

What Economic Forces Drive Energy Market Resilience During Supply Shocks?

Despite production curtailments equivalent to 15% of national oil output, energy markets displayed surprising resilience through sophisticated price discovery mechanisms and inventory management systems. Understanding these stabilising forces provides insight into how modern energy markets absorb extreme supply disruptions without triggering proportional price escalations.

Price Discovery Mechanisms Under Stress

Oil markets demonstrated remarkable stability during the crisis, with Brent crude remaining near $66 per barrel despite massive production losses. This price resilience reflected the operation of multiple market mechanisms that helped absorb the supply shock without triggering panic-driven price escalations.

The oil price forecast analysis suggests that markets had already factored in potential weather-related disruptions. Moreover, forward market positioning, strategic inventory buffers, and market expectations of rapid supply recovery combined to prevent severe price escalation during the acute shortage period.

Natural gas markets showed more dramatic price responses, reflecting the commodity's limited storage capacity and immediate demand-supply balance requirements. Henry Hub futures reached $6.80 per MMBtu on Monday, representing a three-year high, before moderating to $6.55 per MMBtu by Tuesday.

The rapid price retreat suggested market confidence in supply restoration within days rather than weeks. The futures curve revealed sophisticated market expectations about recovery timing, with a $3.00 per MMBtu spread between February and March contracts indicating traders expected supply constraints to resolve within 4-6 weeks.

Regional Market Segmentation Effects

Geographic price differentials during the storm highlighted how transmission constraints create submarkets within national energy systems. The PJM Interconnection's $638 per megawatt-hour electricity prices compared to New York's $680 per megawatt-hour reflected varying degrees of supply stress and transmission capacity between regional grids.

These price disparities created arbitrage opportunities for market participants with flexible delivery capabilities, while revealing the limitations of physical infrastructure to balance supply and demand across regions during extreme events. However, US natural gas forecast models may need to incorporate more frequent extreme weather scenarios.

Demand Elasticity Under Extreme Conditions

Heating demand surged to 156 billion cubic feet per day during the storm week, compared to the five-year January average of 137 bcf per day. This 13.8% increase in demand coincided with supply disruptions, creating the perfect conditions for price volatility.

Industrial demand response programmes activated automatically as electricity prices reached extreme levels, with energy-intensive manufacturers curtailing operations to avoid peak pricing exposure. This demand flexibility helped prevent even more severe price spikes by reducing total system load during critical periods.

How Do Weather Events Reshape Energy Investment Priorities?

Winter Storm Fern's impact has triggered fundamental reassessment of infrastructure investment priorities across the energy sector. The scale of production losses and price volatility demonstrated that current winterization efforts remain inadequate for extreme weather scenarios, driving new capital allocation toward resilience rather than pure capacity expansion.

Infrastructure Hardening Economics

The storm's economic impact provides compelling justification for increased winterization investments. With 2 million barrels per day of oil production curtailed at $66 per barrel for seven days, the immediate production loss exceeded $920 million.

Natural gas curtailments added approximately $455 million in lost production value, creating total weekly losses exceeding $1.38 billion. Furthermore, these losses underscore the importance of robust energy security strategies that can withstand extreme weather events.

Winterisation Investment Category Estimated Cost Range Payback Period Wellhead freeze protection systems $10,000-50,000 per well 2-3 extreme weather events Pipeline insulation and heating $1-5 million per mile 5-7 years Compressor station cold-weather upgrades $5-25 million per facility 3-5 years Power generation dual-fuel capability $50-200 million per plant 7-10 years

Equipment-specific vulnerabilities identified during the storm provide clear targets for infrastructure improvements. Wellhead freeze-offs emerged as the primary production loss mechanism, particularly in the Bakken Basin where temperatures overwhelmed existing protection systems.

Compressor station failures created cascade effects throughout natural gas distribution networks, as these critical facilities could not maintain pressure during extreme cold conditions. Pipeline capacity constraints further amplified supply disruptions when transport infrastructure could not accommodate alternative routing around affected areas.

Strategic Reserve Utilisation Patterns

Emergency fuel switching capabilities proved crucial for maintaining electricity generation during natural gas supply constraints. Power plants with dual-fuel capacity activated backup systems using stored oil products, preventing even more severe electricity shortages.

The crisis highlighted the value of strategic fuel inventories positioned near critical infrastructure. Facilities with on-site storage capabilities maintained operations longer than those dependent on just-in-time delivery systems, demonstrating the importance of inventory buffers for extreme weather resilience.

Market Structure Evolution Post-Crisis

Regulatory authorities activated emergency protocols that waived certain environmental restrictions and expedited fuel transportation permits. The Department of Energy's emergency authorities enabled rapid response coordination, while grid operators implemented demand response programmes to manage peak loads.

These emergency measures revealed both the flexibility and limitations of existing market structures. While authorities could temporarily modify regulations to address immediate crises, the underlying infrastructure vulnerabilities require longer-term structural solutions.

What Are the Broader Macroeconomic Implications of Energy Supply Volatility?

Energy price volatility during extreme weather events creates ripple effects throughout the broader economy, impacting everything from manufacturing costs to household budgets. Winter Storm Fern's economic implications extended far beyond energy sector losses, affecting economic activity across multiple industries and regions.

GDP Impact Modelling from Energy Disruptions

Electricity price escalations of 1,400-1,900% above normal winter levels created immediate cost pressures for energy-intensive industries. Manufacturing facilities in the PJM Interconnection region faced unprecedented input cost increases, with some operations suspending production to avoid exposure to peak wholesale prices.

Quantifiable Weekly Economic Impact:

• Oil production losses: $924 million (2 million b/d × 7 days × $66/barrel)

• Natural gas production losses: $455 million (10 bcf/d × 7 days × $6.55/MMBtu)

• Electricity cost escalation: Regional industrial sectors facing 14-19x normal power costs

• Total measurable impact: $1.38+ billion in direct energy production losses

According to Bank of America's analysis, the winter storm Fern impact on US energy markets could significantly affect first-quarter economic growth projections.

Inflation Transmission Mechanisms

Natural gas price spikes translate directly to heating costs for residential and commercial customers, with spot market exposure varying by utility contract structure. The 60-130% increase in heating costs during peak demand periods placed significant burden on household budgets across cold-weather regions.

Transportation fuel costs escalated during port loading disruptions, adding 2-5% to logistics expenses for goods movement throughout the affected regions. These cost increases typically propagate through supply chains over 4-6 weeks following the initial disruption.

Financial Market Responses to Energy Volatility

Market participants recognised that weather-related production cuts are typically temporary, with rapid recovery expected once normal temperatures return. The temporary nature of weather disruptions limits their impact on long-term company valuations, despite massive supply disruptions.

Commodity futures markets displayed sophisticated risk pricing, with natural gas futures showing extreme volatility while oil futures remained relatively stable. This divergence reflected the different storage capabilities and demand elasticity characteristics of each commodity.

Insurance sector exposure became apparent as claims mounted from frozen equipment and business interruption losses. Energy infrastructure insurance rates typically increase following major weather events as insurers reassess risk models and coverage terms.

How Does Geopolitical Context Amplify Domestic Energy Vulnerabilities?

Winter Storm Fern's domestic energy disruptions occurred against a backdrop of complex international energy relationships that limited alternative supply options. Existing sanctions regimes and trade restrictions reduced the flexibility to compensate for domestic production losses through increased imports.

Strategic Resource Security During Crisis

Import dependency risks became apparent when domestic production cuts could not be immediately offset through increased foreign supplies. Sanctions on Russian energy imports, while strategically important, limited alternative supply sources during the domestic shortage period.

The crisis highlighted the timing challenges in activating alternative supply sources. LNG cargoes require 2-3 weeks lead time for delivery, while pipeline imports face capacity constraints during peak demand periods. These logistical realities emphasise the importance of domestic production reliability.

Sanctions Regime Interactions with Market Dynamics

Existing restrictions on Venezuelan oil market participation limited supply flexibility during the domestic production disruption. Chinese refiners reportedly paused Venezuelan crude purchases due to political uncertainties, further constraining alternative supply activation.

Middle Eastern suppliers faced their own seasonal demand peaks, limiting their ability to provide additional volumes to US markets during the crisis period. This timing coincidence demonstrates how global energy markets can become constrained when multiple regions face simultaneous supply or demand pressures.

Alliance Energy Cooperation Frameworks

Emergency fuel sharing agreements with allied nations provided limited relief due to transportation and infrastructure constraints. While cooperation frameworks exist, the physical realities of energy logistics limit their effectiveness during acute shortage periods.

Strategic coordination with major consuming nations helped prevent competitive bidding for scarce supplies, but the fundamental shortage required domestic production recovery rather than import solutions.

What Long-Term Structural Changes Could Emerge from Weather-Driven Energy Crises?

Winter Storm Fern's impact is likely to catalyse significant changes in energy infrastructure investment priorities, regulatory frameworks, and technology adoption patterns. The crisis demonstrated that current approaches to weather resilience remain inadequate for extreme events that are becoming more frequent and severe.

Technology Adoption Acceleration

Distributed generation investment is expected to accelerate following grid reliability concerns exposed during the storm. Businesses and institutions recognise that on-site power generation provides protection against regional grid failures and extreme wholesale price exposure.

Energy storage deployment for supply security enhancement represents a growing investment priority. Battery systems and other storage technologies can provide backup power during grid disruptions while helping manage demand during peak pricing periods.

Smart grid technologies for demand response optimisation showed their value during the crisis, enabling automated load reduction when electricity prices reached extreme levels. These systems will likely see expanded deployment as utilities seek more sophisticated demand management capabilities.

Furthermore, the renewable energy transition must consider resilience factors alongside decarbonisation goals to ensure reliable energy supply during extreme weather events.

Regulatory Framework Evolution

Mandatory winterisation standards are expected to evolve following repeated infrastructure failures during extreme weather events. Current voluntary guidelines have proven insufficient for protecting critical energy infrastructure during severe cold conditions.

Emergency response protocol standardisation across regions could improve coordination during multi-state energy crises. The storm revealed gaps in cross-border cooperation and resource sharing that hampered response effectiveness, as highlighted by experts studying grid vulnerabilities.

Market design modifications for extreme weather resilience may include capacity payments for winterised equipment and performance penalties for facilities that fail during emergency conditions.

Investment Capital Reallocation Patterns

Investment Priority Pre-Storm Allocation Post-Storm Trend Capacity expansion 70% 50% Weather hardening 15% 35% Backup systems 10% 12% Smart grid technology 5% 8%

Infrastructure hardening versus capacity expansion trade-offs are shifting toward resilience investments. Companies recognise that additional capacity provides limited value if weather events can disable large portions of existing infrastructure.

Regional investment flows are redirecting toward weather-resilient assets in areas prone to extreme weather events. This geographic reallocation reflects growing awareness of climate-related infrastructure risks.

ESG considerations in energy infrastructure development increasingly emphasise climate adaptation and resilience rather than solely focusing on emissions reduction. Investors recognise that infrastructure vulnerability to weather events creates significant financial risks.

FAQ: Understanding Energy Market Dynamics During Extreme Weather

Why didn't oil prices surge more dramatically despite massive production cuts?

Strategic inventory levels, forward market positioning, and expectations of rapid supply recovery helped absorb the immediate supply shock. Oil markets have sophisticated mechanisms for managing temporary disruptions that distinguish them from longer-term supply constraints.

How do electricity markets handle extreme demand spikes?

Regional grid operators activate emergency protocols including demand response programmes, emergency generation capacity, and load shedding procedures. Price signals encourage demand reduction while emergency authorities can waive certain regulations to secure additional supply.

What makes natural gas infrastructure particularly vulnerable to cold weather?

Natural gas systems face multiple cold-weather vulnerabilities including wellhead freeze-offs, compressor station failures, and pipeline capacity constraints. Unlike oil, natural gas has limited storage capability, making supply disruptions immediately apparent in pricing.

How do energy companies prepare for extreme weather events?

Preparation includes winterisation investments, emergency response planning, strategic inventory positioning, and backup fuel arrangements. However, winter storm Fern impact on US energy markets demonstrated that current preparation levels remain inadequate for extreme scenarios.

What role do government agencies play during energy emergencies?

Federal authorities can waive environmental regulations, coordinate emergency fuel supplies, activate strategic reserves, and facilitate interstate cooperation. The Department of Energy's emergency authorities proved crucial for response coordination during Winter Storm Fern.

Disclaimer: This analysis is based on publicly available information and market data. Energy market conditions and infrastructure vulnerabilities can change rapidly. Readers should consult current sources and professional advisors for investment or operational decisions. Weather-related energy disruptions involve significant uncertainties, and future events may differ from historical patterns discussed in this analysis.

name: Clean Energy
title: Opinion: Ohio's opportunity to lead in clean energy competitiveness
authors: Crain's Cleveland Business, www.facebook.com, Emily Keller-Dey
description:
And as executives look forward, the one issue that hums around every strategy session and board meeting is access to affordable, reliable, and increasingly clean energy.
By improving our energy policies to reflect business desires, companies seeking clean, affordable power will invest, expand and innovate in Ohio.
In Greater Cleveland, our companies have a strong demand for clean energy, spending tens of millions of dollars each year on renewable energy credits (RECs).
Across the country, rural Republican districts are experiencing some of the greatest job growth and tax-revenue gains from renewable energy projects.
Furthermore, renewable energy development creates jobs across construction, engineering, advanced manufacturing and long-term operations.
text:
Famous Ohio inventor Charles F. Kettering once credited his forward-looking perspective for his prolific career. “My interest is in the future,” he said, “because I am going to spend the rest of my life there.”

The most successful businesses operate the same way. And as executives look forward, the one issue that hums around every strategy session and board meeting is access to affordable, reliable, and increasingly clean energy. Ohio businesses want to invest here and are eager for solutions.

Roughly half of all Fortune 500 companies now have renewable energy or sustainability commitments. For many of them, those commitments are now embedded in capital allocation decisions, site selection, and long-term cost planning. When these companies decide where to expand, where to build, or where to relocate, access to clean, affordable power is no longer a “nice to have.” It is a requirement and thus also a business opportunity.

States that align with these needs are attracting growth, and Ohio is well-positioned to do the same with the right policies.

Ohio’s skilled workforce, manufacturing strength, and central location position the state well for continued growth. By improving our energy policies to reflect business desires, companies seeking clean, affordable power will invest, expand and innovate in Ohio.

In Greater Cleveland, our companies have a strong demand for clean energy, spending tens of millions of dollars each year on renewable energy credits (RECs). Today, those millions of megawatt-hours are sourced from other states because Ohio’s current policies make it difficult to meet locally. With the right conditions, that investment could be captured at home, fueling in-state renewable projects, creating jobs, supporting landowners, and strengthening local communities. Scaled across Ohio, this opportunity reaches well into the hundreds of millions annually.

There are lessons we could learn from other states.

Indiana is attracting large-scale solar investment and outpacing Ohio in Midwest clean-energy competitiveness; Iowa generates more than 60% percent of its electricity from wind and solar; and Texas is the top state for renewable energy development. Across the country, rural Republican districts are experiencing some of the greatest job growth and tax-revenue gains from renewable energy projects.

But here in Ohio, we’re falling behind, and it is already costing real investment.

Fortunately, we have begun moving in the right direction. The bipartisan passage of Ohio House Bill 15 marked a meaningful step toward modernizing our energy policy by rolling back outdated subsidies and signaling that Ohio is serious about competitiveness, affordability, and reliability. While no single bill solves everything, HB 15 created important momentum and demonstrated that progress is possible when policymakers focus on Ohio’s long-term economic future. Now is the time to build on that foundation and keep moving forward.

But the tech companies are also looking for other forms of clean energy. Meta recently announced an investment to support Vistra’s nuclear facilities on Lake Erie here in Greater Cleveland, signaling strong corporate demand for reliable, carbon-free energy and the economic potential that comes with it.

When renewable projects do advance in Ohio, communities feel clear and tangible benefits. In Brown County, for example, from one solar project, landowners received substantial proceeds and the project payments accounted for 11% of the county’s 2024 budget. Furthermore, renewable energy development creates jobs across construction, engineering, advanced manufacturing and long-term operations.

This success could be replicated across the state. Ohio’s ability to compete depends on an “all of the above” energy strategy that is affordable and reliable, with carbon-free generation as an essential part of the mix. Across Ohio, business leaders are increasingly aligned around a common set of priorities to meet rising demand and keep the state competitive: preserving customer choice in a market-based energy system, investing in transmission infrastructure, controlling costs while improving reliability, and removing regulatory barriers that limit in-state generation. These principles are shared by organizations like the Greater Cleveland Partnership and the Ohio Business Energy Partnership and reflect what employers across the state need to grow, invest and create jobs in Ohio.

Emily Keller-Dey is the Director of Sustainability Initiatives at the Greater Cleveland Partnership, the region’s leading economic development organization, and is on the board of The Ohio Business Energy Partnership (OBEP).

name: EVs
title: Detroit's Great Recalibration: GM Takes $7.2 Billion EV Charge While Rewarding Shareholders
description:
The Cost of Realignment The $7.2 billion charge announced by General Motors represents one of the largest strategic pivots in the company's 117-year history.
The bulk of the impairment—approximately $6.1 billion—is tied directly to the North American EV segment.
In the short term, investors can expect GM to report robust "EBIT-Adjusted" profits, projected between $13 billion and $15 billion for 2026.
However, if a future administration restores EV mandates, GM may find itself lagging behind global competitors who stayed the course on pure electrification.
Final Assessment for Investors The $7.2 billion charge taken by General Motors marks the official transition from the "Visionary" phase of the EV era to the "Pragmatic" phase.
text:
On January 27, 2026, General Motors (NYSE: GM) signaled a definitive end to the "all-in" electric vehicle era that had defined its corporate strategy for the previous half-decade. In a sweeping fourth-quarter earnings report, the Detroit giant announced a massive $7.2 billion special charge related to a strategic "realignment" of its EV operations and a restructuring of its presence in China. The immediate financial impact was stark, as the company reported a $3.3 billion net loss for the final quarter of 2025, driven largely by the costs of scaling back manufacturing capacity and canceling underperforming product lines.

However, the market's reaction was tempered by a aggressive shift in capital allocation. Alongside the multi-billion dollar write-down, GM management authorized a new $6.0 billion share repurchase program and a 20% increase in its quarterly dividend to $0.18 per share. This "pivot to profit" underscores a new reality for the American automotive industry: while electrification remains a long-term goal, the immediate priority has shifted back to the high-margin, internal combustion engine (ICE) and hybrid vehicles that currently bankroll the transition.

The Cost of Realignment

The $7.2 billion charge announced by General Motors represents one of the largest strategic pivots in the company's 117-year history. The bulk of the impairment—approximately $6.1 billion—is tied directly to the North American EV segment. This includes $1.8 billion in non-cash asset write-downs for specialized EV assembly lines that will now be idled or converted to "flexible" production, and $4.3 billion in cash-related costs. These cash costs include hefty contract termination fees for battery suppliers and the scrubbing of several mid-tier electric SUV programs that were deemed no longer viable in the current market.

The remaining $1.1 billion of the charge is attributed to a painful restructuring of GM’s long-standing joint venture in China with SAIC. Once a cornerstone of GM’s global profits, the Chinese market has become increasingly hostile for foreign legacy automakers as local brands dominate the affordable EV space. GM’s move to write down these assets follows a trend of "onshoring" production back to the United States, a strategy punctuated by the company's decision to move production of the Buick Envision from China to North American facilities to avoid rising trade tensions and tariffs.

CEO Mary Barra, who once famously pledged that GM would go "all-electric by 2035," framed the announcement as a necessary "recalibration" during the company's January 27th earnings call. Barra pointed to a "dynamic" regulatory environment and a shift in consumer behavior as the primary catalysts for the move. By taking the hit now, GM aims to clean up its balance sheet and focus on its most profitable segments: the Chevrolet Silverado, the GMC Sierra, and the Cadillac Escalade.

Winners and Losers in the Pivot to Pragmatism

The primary "winners" in this strategic shift are legacy GM shareholders, who are seeing a massive return of capital despite the quarterly loss. By reducing its total share count—which has fallen from 1.2 billion in 2023 to roughly 904 million by the end of 2025—GM is artificially boosting its earnings per share (EPS) for the coming years. Similarly, Ford Motor Company (NYSE: F) stands to benefit from a more rationalized competitive landscape; Ford took its own $19.5 billion "cleansing" charge in late 2025, and both companies are now aligned in prioritizing hybrid technology over pure-play battery electric vehicles (BEVs).

Conversely, pure-play EV manufacturers are facing a brutal 2026. Tesla, Inc. (NASDAQ: TSLA) has been particularly hard hit by the regulatory fallout that accompanied GM's pivot. The termination of the "inter-manufacturer credit trading system"—a mechanism that allowed Tesla to sell billions in regulatory credits to companies like GM—has stripped the company of a high-margin revenue stream. Furthermore, the expiration of federal EV tax credits in late 2025 has put immense pressure on companies like Rivian Automotive (NASDAQ: RIVN) and Lucid Group (NASDAQ: LCID), which lack the profitable gasoline-powered portfolios that GM and Ford are now leaning on for survival.

The losers also include the global battery supply chain. GM's cancellation of specific product programs and the $4.3 billion in termination fees suggest that battery demand is significantly lower than projected three years ago. Companies that invested heavily in North American lithium-ion gigafactories are now facing "demand air pockets" that may take years to fill.

A Broader Shift in the Industrial Landscape

GM’s $7.2 billion charge is not an isolated event but rather a symptom of a broader tectonic shift in U.S. industrial policy and consumer reality. The enactment of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act (OBBBA) in July 2025 served as the death knell for the previous administration’s EV mandates. By replacing EV-specific tax credits with a universal auto loan interest deduction, the federal government effectively removed the "thumb on the scale" for electric vehicles, allowing consumer demand to dictate the pace of the transition.

Furthermore, the recent rollbacks of EPA and NHTSA standards have removed the legal threat of massive fines that previously forced automakers to push EVs into a reluctant market. The "SAFE III" rule, proposed in December 2025, significantly lowered fuel economy requirements, giving GM and its peers the "regulatory breathing room" to extend the life cycles of their high-margin V-8 and hybrid powertrains. Historically, this mirrors the early 2000s, when a similar softening of standards led to the "SUV boom"—a period of intense profitability for Detroit that was eventually interrupted by the 2008 financial crisis.

The pivot also highlights the collapse of the "California Waiver," which previously allowed the state to set its own more stringent emissions rules. With the federal government revoking this waiver in 2025, GM is no longer required to manage two separate national fleets, leading to massive logistical and manufacturing efficiencies that the company is now trying to capture through its $6 billion buyback program.

What Lies Ahead: The Era of Flexible Manufacturing

Looking forward, GM’s strategy for 2026 and beyond is built on "flexible manufacturing." The company has guided for a modest 300,000 EVs in 2026—a far cry from its previous million-unit ambitions—while focusing heavily on "Extended-Range Electric Vehicles" (EREVs) and traditional hybrids. This approach allows the company to scale production based on real-time consumer demand rather than regulatory mandates.

In the short term, investors can expect GM to report robust "EBIT-Adjusted" profits, projected between $13 billion and $15 billion for 2026. The challenge will be managing the "messy middle" of the transition. If gas prices remain relatively low and interest rates stabilize, GM’s focus on high-margin trucks and generous shareholder returns could lead to a significant re-rating of its stock. However, if a future administration restores EV mandates, GM may find itself lagging behind global competitors who stayed the course on pure electrification.

Final Assessment for Investors

The $7.2 billion charge taken by General Motors marks the official transition from the "Visionary" phase of the EV era to the "Pragmatic" phase. GM has effectively admitted that its 2021 roadmaps were overly optimistic, but in doing so, it has cleared the path for a massive return of capital to its owners. For the market, this move signals that "growth at any cost" in the EV space is over; profitability and cash flow are once again the primary metrics of success in the automotive sector.

Investors should watch for the margin performance of GM’s new hybrid lineup and the pace of its share repurchases. While the $3.3 billion loss in Q4 2025 looks ugly on paper, it is likely the "big bath" that sets the stage for a leaner, more profitable GM in the late 2020s. The Detroit giant is betting that the road to the future isn't paved just with batteries, but with the cash generated by the legendary internal combustion engines of the present.

This content is intended for informational purposes only and is not financial advice

title: Can America keep the lights on? What needs to happen to modernize the grid | Charlotte Observer
description:
Over the next 25 years, electricity demand is projected to climb by more than 50%, fueled by the widespread electrification of industries, transportation, and daily life.
This surge in demand signals exciting progress, but it also raises an urgent question: Can the nation's aging power grid keep up?
AI Alone Could Break the Grid One of the biggest drivers of this new demand?
This rapid growth underscores the urgent need to build a grid that can keep pace with innovation.
Much of the US Grid Is Decades Past Its Prime Part of the challenge lies in the age of the infrastructure itself.
text:
As artificial intelligence accelerates innovation and electric vehicles shift from novelty to norm, the United States is on the brink of an energy transformation. Over the next 25 years, electricity demand is projected to climb by more than 50%, fueled by the widespread electrification of industries, transportation, and daily life.

This surge in demand signals exciting progress, but it also raises an urgent question: Can the nation's aging power grid keep up? A compelling October 2025 visual report from ELSCO Transformers highlights both the incredible potential of this electric future and the infrastructure challenges we must address to get there.

From data centers and EV charging stations to clean energy initiatives, America's growing appetite for electricity is driving conversations about infrastructure investment and planning.

AI Alone Could Break the Grid

One of the biggest drivers of this new demand? Artificial intelligence. While AI is revolutionizing industries and boosting productivity across the board, it's also becoming a major energy consumer. Each server request can require four to five watt-hours of electricity, a small number on its own, but when multiplied by billions of daily interactions, the impact quickly scales.

In fact, AI-related server usage is expected to consume 15 million megawatt-hours annually by 2027, enough to power millions of American homes every year. This rapid growth underscores the urgent need to build a grid that can keep pace with innovation.

Much of the US Grid Is Decades Past Its Prime

Part of the challenge lies in the age of the infrastructure itself. According to the report, nearly 70% of power transformers and transmission lines are more than 25 years old and rapidly approaching the end of their usable life.

Much of the U.S. grid was originally designed in the 1950s through the 1970s, long before today's energy demands were even imaginable.

Now, with more than 60,000 miles of transmission lines already running at full capacity, the system is stretched thin, raising questions about the need for upgrades.

Fixing It Could Cost $5T, But Inaction Will Cost More

Looking ahead, meeting the projected demand of 5,178 terawatt-hours by 2050 will require more than just innovation; it will require massive investment.

The cost of replacing and upgrading the nation's power infrastructure is estimated at a staggering $5 trillion, driven by rising material prices, supply chain pressures, and long lead times for essential components like transformers.

It's a daunting figure, but it's one that reflects the scale of transformation needed to build a grid capable of powering the next generation.

Interconnection Queues Are a Major Bottleneck

Even promising solutions like renewable energy, often seen as the key to a cleaner, more sustainable future, are facing significant hurdles. Despite widespread support, nearly 80% of proposed power generation projects are being delayed or canceled due to interconnection queue bottlenecks and regulatory backlogs.

These slowdowns are preventing clean energy from reaching the grid at the pace required, underscoring the need for streamlined processes and faster approvals if we're serious about meeting tomorrow's energy demands.

Industry Recommendations

To meet these challenges head-on, the report outlines a three-pronged strategy for building a more resilient and future-ready grid:

Diversify energy sources: Industry proposals include quadrupling the share of federally sourced renewable energy by 2035, reducing reliance on aging fossil-fuel infrastructure.

Accelerate interconnection: The report recommends doubling the speed at which new energy projects, especially renewables, are connected to the grid, cutting through red tape and backlogs.

Streamline equipment manufacturing: Another proposal involves prioritizing high-availability components with faster production, shorter shipping times, and long-term warranties to minimize delays and downtime.

These proposals represent one practical roadmap for powering America's electric future sustainably, securely, and at scale.

The bottom line? The U.S. doesn't have an energy shortage; it has an infrastructure bottleneck. With 2.6 terawatt-hours of generation capacity currently sitting idle due to outdated systems and regulatory delays, the potential is already there.

This story was produced by ELSCO Transformers and reviewed and distributed by Stacker.

Stacker National

This story was originally published January 27, 2026 at 4:30 AM.

name: American Energy
title: The One Big Beautiful Prediction: The Energy Transition Is Still Alive - Capital & Main
description:
A scholar of energy justice and the energy transition, Carley said the whiplash of the last year has undoubtedly hurt consumers and decarbonization efforts alike.
But, she said, she’s certain “The energy transition is still underway.” This interview has been edited for clarity and brevity.
A lot of your work focuses on the human costs of the energy transition.
We are still seeing significant clean energy development, distributed energy resources, all of these things are moving forward.
The energy transition is still underway, but the whiplash has very serious implications for our economy and for the investment culture of America.
text:
Three weeks after the Nov. 5, 2024, election that ushered President Donald Trump back into power, Sanya Carley, the faculty director of the Kleinman Center for Energy Policy at the University of Pennsylvania, and co-author of the book Power Lines: The Human Costs of American Energy in Transition, penned an op-ed in the Philadelphia Inquirer with a series of predictions that proved to be prophetic.

On his campaign promise to “drill, baby, drill,” she forecasted, “President Trump will prioritize executive orders — likely in his first few days in office — that open more federal lands to oil and gas leasing and reduce the permitting and other regulatory requirements associated with drilling and extraction operations.”

In a matter of months, that came true, as did her premonition that Trump would “introduce an executive order early in his term seeking to slow or delay the permitting process for offshore wind projects,” and eliminate the Biden-era Justice40 initiative that sought to ensure 40% of federal climate investments go to communities overburdened by pollution.

The months that followed have been marked by a slew of attacks on renewable energy from all angles and across multiple agencies and branches of government. A year into Trump’s second presidency, Capital & Main caught up with Carley to discuss what’s happened, her predictions and how they’ve played out. A scholar of energy justice and the energy transition, Carley said the whiplash of the last year has undoubtedly hurt consumers and decarbonization efforts alike. But, she said, she’s certain “The energy transition is still underway.”

This interview has been edited for clarity and brevity.

Capital & Main: Before we discuss the year since Jan. 20, 2025, I want to start by backing up even further, to November of 2024 with your op-ed in the Inquirer. Your predictions came true with startling accuracy. Take me back to that time.

Sanya Carley: Well, exactly as predicted, he did, in fact, issue a number of executive orders. That is the tool that he used previously in the first Trump administration — a series of executive orders. I would call it the administrative presidency — relying very heavily on executive force. What’s really quite interesting this new time is it’s an administrative presidency on steroids. The use of a slew of executive orders, just a bombardment of them, but accompanied with emergency declarations, and using these emergencies to be able to use regulatory and policy tools that he might not have been able to otherwise, that might have needed to be approved by Congress.

And that’s also at the same time that there were so many federal employees that were laid off, so people that were administering many of these programs disappeared. And so it was much more, I would argue, than the first presidency, executive orders, accompanied with these other things. Trump has put a lot of judges in place. And as a result, those items that end up in the courts, of which there are many, there are now more judges that are deciding in favor of Trump than there were previously. So those are the kind of elements of this all happening at once.

It seems like the administration has taken an all-hands-on-deck approach to halting the clean energy transition — between executive orders, orders from agency heads and Trump signing bills sent to him by Congress. The administration has gutted agencies, repealed tax credits and grants and ordered certain renewable projects closed and other fossil fuel ones to stay open. Have any of these deregulatory mechanisms been more impactful than others?

The repeal of [core components of] the [Inflation Reduction Act] in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act is probably the most impactful. There were so many prongs. There were so many efforts embedded within the IRA focused on clean energy development, but also job development and creation and justice elements, and all of those have been affected by the pullback of the IRA programs.

You mention the energy emergency declaration. It’s interesting because, when the administration issued this, scholars and environmentalists quickly debunked it, pointing to record fossil fuel production. But an energy affordability emergency is now taking shape, and that has largely been spurred by the growth of data centers. Efforts to dismantle clean energy development don’t seem to be doing much to help it. What kind of emergency do you think is really happening?

I think the emergency in the Trump administration’s mind is that we’re headed on a track towards a clean energy transition, and we need to shift. I think the emergency in the minds of the majority of Americans is that we have an affordability crisis. The two are kind of colliding, and so a lot of the chaos that the Trump administration is creating in the energy industry is leading to abandoned projects, it’s leading to situations where power plants are being forced to run even though they’re not economically efficient or economically appropriate to run, and demand is going up significantly from data centers.

But the administration has essentially done everything it can to remove any guardrails for the development of these data centers and to encourage fossil fuel growth at the same time, and so as a result, there will be a lot more investment in fossil fuels going forward to provide for these data centers. And all of these things will add costs, so they will contribute to the affordability crisis.

Just to be very concrete, forcing a coal power plant to stay online adds significant costs to ratepayers in any given location surrounding these plants.

What do these costs look like? I’m thinking of the Eddystone power plant near Philadelphia that was slated to retire in May before the administration ordered it to stay open.

It’s either passed to the consumers directly as a rider or a charger, which is essentially just a very direct cost to cover something that’s spread across all of the customers, or as a result of costs going up for the utility company, they go to the Public Utility Commission and ask for a new rate case so that they can raise rates. And what we’re seeing happening right now is rate cases are proliferating, and energy bills just continue to go up. Energy prices have risen on average 30% over the past five years across America — faster than the rate of inflation.

A lot of your work focuses on the human costs of the energy transition. Were there any mistakes that the Biden administration made in ushering in a renewable energy era that we could now learn from?

There are plenty of places where the Biden administration, through the Inflation Reduction Act and the Infrastructure Act, made great progress in thinking about humans and thinking about justice issues in particular. One example is tax credits for electric vehicles and changing the eligibility requirements. This just helps those low-income customers that wouldn’t have been able to afford an electric vehicle or didn’t have the tax liability to be able to recover some of those credits. So it’s an example of taking an existing policy and tweaking it a little bit so that it’s more inclusive and thereby reaches a broader population.

And now, we’re in a moment of whiplash. Many deregulatory steps from the administration have been met by legal challenges, so we’ve been in a limbo on many fronts for a while. What impact is that having on the overall energy transition?

Well, the whiplash and the route to litigation is very consistent with the first Trump administration. So we’re seeing common threads. Even just this week, there’s some early thinking that the repeal of IRA funding that went to blue states was illegal and that those funds need to be reinstated. What is the consequence of the whiplash? The energy transition is still moving forward. We are still seeing significant solar development. We are still seeing significant clean energy development, distributed energy resources, all of these things are moving forward.

The energy transition is still underway, but the whiplash has very serious implications for our economy and for the investment culture of America. No new company is going to want to move to America right now and try to build offshore wind. The political environment is way too uncertain. Nobody wants to enter all of these legal battles.

Now, what are the implications for local communities? I’ve written before on the whiplash for coal communities. Coal communities will vote in their best interest, which is to keep coal operations running, even if they desire to have a different future, because that’s the future that they’ve had, and that’s their economic stability. With these kinds of monoeconomies, there’s very little other opportunity for growth. Having this kind of back and forth between administrations of closing all coal plants versus forcing them to stay online, forcing more production, it’s just incredibly difficult for them to kind of think about their long-run trajectory.

It’s hopeful to hear your reminder that the energy transition hasn’t been halted completely. How would you define the last year in the context of decades of change?

If you think of a graph, we’ve seen some plateaus, but I don’t anticipate the plateaus will decline. I anticipate that it’s a plateau to bear through the current political and legal environment before all of these technologies can continue to accelerate. I mentioned solar before. Solar has still been on a phenomenal growth trajectory, especially across the entire world. Again, it’s the leading source of growth in the energy industry in the United States. I think in the next year we might see some challenges with solar, just because the [One Big Beautiful Bill Act] repealed the Investment Tax Credit and Production Tax Credit [for wind and solar], and so as a result, anything that wasn’t already in development by the end of this year will no longer have access to those credits. So we’ll probably see a plateau there, or at least a slowing down of the growth of solar. Generally, we’re still very consistent trend wise.

So, how pessimistic should we feel?

I think we should not be pessimistic. I think we should be optimistic. I think where we can be pessimistic, one, is around the general use of policy and regulation in a way that’s kind of inconsistent with our democratic system, and not knowing what that could lead to in the future. And then, two, is the affordability crisis. That is not brought on by the energy transition, but it is very strongly connected to the policy and regulation of this administration.

So, addressing that challenge going forward, that is something that we can be pessimistic about, but we also need to think very deeply about opportunities for change in the industry. It could be rate reform, thinking about alternative rate design. It could be creating alternatives to certain kinds of markets that are in place, rethinking capacity markets. Another one is a virtual power plant. What kind of stipulations do we want to put on data center growth? These are all the kinds of questions that we need to face right now as we’re addressing affordability challenges.

text:
Today, U.S. Representative Salud Carbajal (D-CA-24) announced new federal funding for projects across Ventura County. The funding was recently approved by Congress and signed into law through the Fiscal Year 2026 government funding bill. The bill includes investments for the Ventura County Sheriff's Office Unidentified and Missing Persons Forensic Genetic Genealogy Testing Initiative and dredging of the Ventura Harbor.

The funding package includes a $700,000 grant for the Ventura County Sheriff's Office Unidentified and Missing Persons Forensic Genetic Genealogy Testing Initiative. The funding will be used to investigate a backlog of unidentified human remains cases in the county.

“We’ve already seen very positive results from this initiative,” said Rep. Carbajal. “In just one quarter in 2024, the Sheriff’s Department and Medical Examiner’s Office used this genetic testing initiative to successfully identify and reunite four Central Coast families with the remains of their loved ones. These reunifications are only the beginning, and it’s critical we deliver the resources needed to bring closure to every family still waiting for answers.”

The funding bill also includes $5,980,000 in grants for the crucial annual dredging of the Ventura Harbor.

“It would be difficult to overstate the importance of the annual dredging project for the economic strength of Ventura County. The project not only ensures successful maritime navigation but is foundational to maintaining the vitality of commercial fishing, local tourism, recreational boating, and waterfront businesses,” said Rep Carbajal.

In the spring of 2025, Carbajal began to push for funding these projects through formal requests to the House Appropriations Committee for Fiscal Year 2026.

name: EVs
title: Downloadable — The Fuel Equation: Gas, Charging and Projections - CStore Decisions
description:
Fuel policy underwent a major shift beginning in January 2025 when the Trump administration signed an executive order eliminating the “electric vehicle (EV) mandate” established during the Biden administration.
The mandate included initiatives such as helping fund public charging networks through the National EV Infrastructure (NEVI) program and investing in EV manufacturing and tax credits with a goal that half of new vehicles sold in 2030 would be zero emission.
While this may have caused uncertainty for some retailers already hesitating on EV, others forged on with their EV charging plans.
Read more below about how retailers are navigating the evolving landscape in CStore Decisions’ January cover story.
